x.explanation: The 24th letter of the modern English alphabet.
Any of the speech sounds represented by the letter x.
The 24th in a series.
Something shaped like the letter X.
A mark inscribed to represent the signature of one who is unable to sign one's name.
An unknown or unnamed factor, thing, or person.
To mark or sign with an X.
To delete, cancel, or obliterate with a series of X's. Often used with out.
xenon.
electricity , the symbol for reactance in alternating-current circuits.
wireless telegraphy , a local disturbance causing a false signal; a stray.
Christ , as in Xn. (Christian), Xmas. (Christmas).
ornithology , in myological formulas, the symbol of the semitendinosus muscle.
mathematics :
lowercase ] In algebra, the first of the unknown quantities or variables.
l. c] In analytical geometry, an abscissa or other rectilinear point-coördinate.
x.

ks ), as in wax ; a compound vocal sound (that of gz ), as in example ; and, at the beginning of a word, a simple vocal sound (that of z), as in xanthic . See Guide to Pronunciation , §§ 217, 270, 271.
The twenty-fourth letter of the basic modern Latin alphabet .
voiceless velar fricative .
An unknown variable .
The first coordinate in Cartesian coordinates , representing horizontal position.
A kiss at the end of a letter, or similar missive.
The twenty-fourth letter of the English alphabet , called ex and written in the Latin script .
the cardinal number that is the sum of nine and one; the base of the decimal system
street names for methylenedioxymethamphetamine
being one more than nine
the 24th letter of the Roman alphabet

xanthaline.explanation: A pulverulent alkaloid, C 37 H 36 O 9 N 2 , contained in crude opium. It melts at 206° C.

xanthamide.explanation: A colorless compound, H 2 NCS.OC 2 H 5 , prepared by the action of alcoholic ammonia on ethyl xanthate. It crystallizes in monoclinic pyramids and melts at 38° C. Also called xanthogenamide . It is not the amide of xanthic acid.
An amido derivative of xanthic acid obtained as a white crystalline substance, C2H5O.CS.NH2; -- called also xanthogen amide .

xanthan.explanation: A polysaccharide , consisting of galactose and mannose residues, produced by the bacterium Xanthomonas campestris

xanthane.explanation: The radical, C 2 N 2 S 3 , of persulphocyanic acid.

xanthate.explanation: A salt or ester of a xanthic acid, especially a simple xanthic acid salt, as of sodium or potassium, used as a flotation collector for copper, silver, and gold.
A salt of xanthic; a xanthogenate.
Any salt or ester of xanthic acid .
a salt or ester of xanthic acid

xanthein.explanation: That part of the yellow coloring matter in flowers which is soluble in water, as distinguished from xanthin , which is the insoluble part.
The water-soluble part of the yellow carotenoid pigment present in the cell sap of some plants.

xanthelasma.explanation: A deposit of cholesterol on the eyelid .
xanthoma of the eyelids; occurs chiefly in the elderly

xanthelasmoidea.explanation: An affection of the skin occurring in the form of reddish or yellowish wheals, which leave more or less permanent yellowish or brownish patches on the skin: called also urticaria pigmentosa .

xanthene.explanation: A yellow crystalline organic compound, C 13 H 10 O, that is soluble in ether and is used as a fungicide and in organic synthesis. The structural unit of xanthene is a feature in several fluorescent dyes.
Orthomethylenediphenylene oxid; a colorless compound, , prepared by the action of aluminium chlorid on phenol. It crystallizes in plates, melts at 100.5° C., and boils at 315° C.
any of a group of tricyclic heterocycles ( dibenzopyrans ) that are the basis for a range of dyes such as fluorescein and eosin

xanthian.explanation: Of or pertaining to Xanthus, an ancient town on Asia Minor; -- applied especially to certain marbles found near that place, and now in the British Museum.

xanthic.explanation: Tending toward a yellow color, or to one of those colors, green being excepted, in which yellow is a constituent, as scarlet, orange, etc.
Possessing, imparting, or producing a yellow color.
Of or pertaining to xanthic acid, or its compounds; xanthogenic.

a heavy, astringent, colorless oil, C2H5O.CS.SH, having a pungent odor. It is produced by leading carbon disulphide into a hot alcoholic solution of potassium hydroxide. So called from the yellow color of many of its salts. Called also xanthogenic acid .
those colors (of flowers) having some tinge of yellow; -- opposed to cyanic colors . See under Cyanic .

xanthide.explanation: A compound or derivative of xanthogen.

xanthidium.explanation: A name applied to the fossil spore-cases of desmidean Algæ and also to the statoblasts of Polyzoa : found in rocks of various ages.

A genus of minute unicellular algæ of the desmids. These algæ have a rounded shape and are armed with glochidiate or branched aculei. Several species occur in ditches, and others are found fossil in flint or hornstone.

xanthin.explanation: One of several substances, so named with reference to their color. (
A yellow insoluble coloring matter extracted from yellow flowers; specifically, the coloring matter of madder.
One of the gaseous or volatile decomposition products of the xanthates, and probably identical with carbon disulphide.

xanthine.explanation: A yellowish-white, crystalline purine base, C 5 H 4 N 4 O 2 , that is a precursor of uric acid and is found in blood, urine, muscle tissue, and certain plants.
Any of several derivatives of this compound.
Any of a group of alkaloids , that include caffeine , theophylline , and theobromine as well as the parent compound , a precursor of uric acid found in many organs of the body.
crystalline oxidation product of the metabolism of nucleoproteins; precursor of uric acid; found in many organs and in urine

xanthinuria.explanation: The excretion of xanthin in abnormal quantity in the urine. Also xanthuria .
An abnormally high level of xanthine in one's urine .
The genetic disorder that causes this.

xanthism.explanation: a yellowish colouring of pigments in hair, skin, feathers, etc.

xanthite.explanation: A variety of vesuvianite found in limestone near Amity, New York.
A variety of vesuvianite found in limestone near Amity, New York.

xanthium.explanation: A genus of composite plants, of the tribe Helianthoideæ and subtribe Ambrosieæ.
A genus of composite plants in which the scales of the involucre are united so as to form a kind of bur; cocklebur; clotbur.
coarse herbs having small heads of greenish flowers followed by burrs with hooked bristles

xanthiuria.explanation: The presence of xanthine in the urine , especially if resulting from defective synthesis of xanthine oxidase

xanthocephalus.explanation: A genus of Icteridæ , or American blackbirds, having as type the common yellow-headed blackbird of the United States, first described by Bonaparte in 1825 as Icterus icterocephalus , and now known as X. icterocephalus.

xanthoceras.explanation: A genus of North China plants, of the family Sapindaceæ.

xanthochroi.explanation: In ethnology , one of the five groups into which some anthropologists classify man, comprising the blond type, or fair whites.
A division of the Caucasian races, comprising the lighter-colored members.

xanthochroia.explanation: A yellow discoloration of the skin resulting from pigmentary changes. Also xanthopathia, xantho-pathy.
A condition characterized by yellow patches on the skin

xanthochroic.explanation: Having a yellowish or fair complexion; of or pertaining to the Xanthochroi.
pertaining to people or races with light hair and pale complexions

xanthochroid.explanation: Having a yellowish or fair complexion.
Pertaining to the Xanthochroi ; having fair hair and a pale complexion .

xanthochroism.explanation: In ornithology , the fact or condition of having abnormally yellow feathers. It occurs most frequently in cases where feathers are normally green, red, or orange, and is often seen in parrots and tanagers.
Abnormal coloration of feathers in which yellow replaces the normal color, as in certain parrots. It is commonly due to lack of the dark pigment which with yellow forms green.

xanthochromia.explanation: The yellowish appearance of cerebrospinal fluid that accompanies certain conditions, especially subarachnoid hemorrhage .

xanthochroous.explanation: Yellow‐skinned; of or pertaining to Xanthochroi .

xanthoconite.explanation: A mineral containing silver , arsenic , and sulphur .

xanthocyanopia.explanation: A form of color-blindness in which there is perception only of yellow and blue; red-green blindness or xanthocyanopsy.

xanthocyanopsy.explanation: Color-blindness in which the ability to distinguish yellow and blue only is present, vision for red being wanting.

xanthoderm.explanation: One who is afflicted by xanthoderma .

xanthoderma.explanation: Yellowness of the skin from any cause; xanthochroia.
A yellow coloration of the skin .

xanthodont.explanation: A person who has yellow teeth

xanthogen.explanation: A hypothetical radical formerly supposed to exist in xanthic acid and its compounds.
The hypothetical radical supposed to be characteristic of xanthic acid.
Formerly, a hypothetical radical supposed to be characteristic of xanthic acid .

xanthogenic.explanation: Producing a yellow color or compound; xanthic. See Xanthic acid, under xanthic .

xanthoma.explanation: A yellowish-orange, lipid-filled nodule or papule in the skin, often on an eyelid or over a joint.
A connective-tissue new growth in the skin, forming soft yellow patches, either flat ( xanthoma planum ) or tuberculated ( xanthoma tuberosum ).
A skin disease marked by the development or irregular yellowish patches upon the skin, especially upon the eyelids; -- called also xanthelasma .
A small, yellow nodule , rich in cholesterol and other lipids , that occurs in the skin , often near a joint
a skin problem marked by the development (on the eyelids and neck and back) of irregular yellow nodules; sometimes attributable to disturbances of cholesterol metabolism

xanthomatosis.explanation: A metabolic disorder characterized by excessive accumulation of lipids in the body and a resulting spread of xanthomas.
A disorder in which excess lipid accumulates in the body and produces xanthomas
widespread xanthomas (especially on elbows and knees); often associated with a disorder of lipid metabolism

xanthomatous.explanation: pathology , of or pertaining to xanthoma: as, the xanthomatous diathesis.
of, or relating to xanthoma or xanthomatosis

xanthomelanous.explanation: Of or pertaining to the lighter division of the Melanochroi, or those races having an olive or yellow complexion and black hair.

xanthometer.explanation: A graduated scale of colors from blue to yellow, white, or green, for determining the color of ocean or lake water. Well-known examples are Forel's scale from blue to olive, for use in the lake of Geneva; O. Krümmel's modification, to which the name ‘xanthometer’ was first given, for use on the plankton expedition of 1890; and the scale of W. Ule of Halle, who extended the scale to 21 numbers.

xanthomonas.explanation: a genus of bacteria similar to Pseudomonas but producing a yellow pigment that is not soluble in water

xanthone.explanation: Dihydroxybenzophenone anhydrid; a colorless compound, , prepared by the oxidation of methylenedipheny-lene oxid. It crystallizes in long needles, melts at 173–174° C., boils at 349–350° C., is volatile with steam, and is the parent substance of a considerable number of natural coloring matters.
An aromatic ketone , 9-oxo-xanthene, that is used as an insecticide .

xanthophane.explanation: A yellow coloring matter derived from the retina.
The yellow pigment present in the inner segments of the retina in animals. See chromophane .

xanthophore.explanation: A yellow to orange chromatophore of a fish, amphibian, or reptile, containing pteridines and carotenoids.
A xanthochrome -containing chromatophore , frequently a lipophore .

xanthophyl.explanation: botany , the peculiar yellow coloring matter of autumn leaves, due to the decomposition of chlorophyl. Its chemical composition and the processes of its formation are not well known. See chlorophyl, chrysophyl. Also called phylloxanthin .
yellow carotenoid pigments in plants and animal fats and egg yolks

xanthophyll.explanation: Any of several yellow carotenoid pigments, including lutein and zeaxanthin, produced by plants and green algae and visible in the leaves of deciduous trees in the autumn. Xanthophylls are also present in some animal tissues such as egg yolks.
A yellow coloring matter found in yellow autumn leaves, and also produced artificially from chlorophyll; -- formerly called also phylloxanthin .
Any of various hydroxy , carbonyl or carboxylic acid derivatives of carotenes .
yellow carotenoid pigments in plants and animal fats and egg yolks

xanthopicrin.explanation: In chem. , a name given by Chevallier and Pelletan to a yellow coloring matter from the bark of Xanthoxylum Caribænm , afterward shown to be identical with berberine.

xanthopicrite.explanation: A bitter crystalline alkaloid extracted from Xanthoxylaceae.

xanthoproteic.explanation: Pertaining to, or derived from, xanthoprotein; showing the characters of xanthoprotein
Of or pertaining to xanthoproteic acid or xanthoproteins .

xanthoprotein.explanation: The characteristic yellow substance formed by the action of hot nitric acid on proteid matters.
A yellow acid substance formed by the action of hot nitric acid on albuminous or proteid matter. It is changed to a deep orange-yellow color by the addition of ammonia.
A protein formed when xanthoproteic acid contacts epithelial cells , indicative of inadequate safety precautions when handling nitric acid .

xanthopsia.explanation: A pathological condition in which objects appear yellow.
A visual defect, a form of chromatopsia in which everything appears yellow .
visual defect in which objects appear to have a yellowish hue; sometimes occurs in cases of jaundice

xanthopsydracia.explanation: The presence of pustules on the skin.
A condition characterized by the occurrence on the skin of small yellow pustules .

xanthopterin.explanation: A yellow pigment found in many insects, especially in the wings of certain butterflies and moths, and also present in the urine of mammals.
A yellow crystalline solid that occurs mainly in the wings of butterflies and in the urine of mammals , converted by microorganisms into folic acid .

xanthopurpurin.explanation: Metadihydroxy-anthraquinone; a yellow compound, C 6 H 4 -, contained in crude natural purpurin and prepared from this substance by reduction. It crystallizes in lustrous needles, melts at 262–263° C., and may be sublimed. Also called purpuroxanthin.

xanthorhamnin.explanation: A glucoside extracted from Persian berries as a yellow crystalline powder, used as a dyestuff.
A chemical compound found in buckthorn berries (Rhamnus catharticus).

xanthorrhiza.explanation: Ranunculaceæ , tribe Helleboreæ , and subtribe Cimicifugeæ.

xanthorrhoea.explanation: Any of the genus Xanthorrhoea of grass trees .

xanthosiderite.explanation: A hydrated ferric oxid, Fe 2 O 3 .2H 2 O, which occurs in fine needles or fibers, also as an ocher, of a golden-yellow to brown or red color.

xanthosis.explanation: In pathology , a yellowish discoloration, especially that sometimes seen in cancerous tumors.
The yellow discoloration often observed in cancerous tumors.
A yellowish discolouration of tissues undergoing degeneration .
an abnormal yellow discoloration of the skin

xanthosoma.explanation: A genus of monocotyledonous plants, of the order Araceæ , tribe Colocasioideæ , and subtribe Colocasieæ.

xanthous.explanation: Yellow; specifically (Ethnol.), of or pertaining to those races of man which have yellowish, red, auburn, or brown hair.
Pertaining to people with yellowish, red, auburn, or brown hair.
of the color intermediate between green and orange in the color spectrum; of something resembling the color of an egg yolk

xanthoxenite.explanation: A dull brown or yellow triclinic mineral .

xanthoxylin.explanation: A colorless, crystalline compound, C 10 H 12 O 4 , contained in Japanese pepper, Xanthoxylum piperitum. It melts at 80° C. and boils without decomposition.

xanthuria.explanation: The presence of xanthine in the urine , especially the presence of a large amount of xanthine due to a metabolic disorder

xanthydrol.explanation: A colorless compound, , prepared by the reduction of xanthone. It crystallizes in microscopic needles and decomposes when heated.

xanthyl.explanation: The univalent radical derived from xanthine

xat.explanation: A carved pole erected as a memorial to the dead by some Indians of Western North America

xcl.explanation: being ten more than one hundred eighty

xdiv.explanation: A way of writing ex div. (which see).

xebec.explanation: A small three-masted Mediterranean vessel with both square and lateen sails.
A small three-masted vessel, formerly much used by the Algerine corsairs, and now in use to some extent in Mediterranean commerce.

A small three-masted vessel, with projecting bow stern and convex decks, used in the Mediterranean for transporting merchandise, etc. It carries large square sails, or both. Xebecs were formerly armed and used by corsairs.
A small, three-masted Mediterranean transport ship

xema.explanation: A genus of Laridæ; the fork-tailed gulls.

xeme.explanation: An Arctic fork-tailed gull ( Xema Sabinii ).

xenelasia.explanation: A Spartan law or alien act which prohibited strangers from residing in Sparta without permission.
A Spartan institution which prohibited strangers from residing in Sparta without permission, its object probably being to preserve the national simplicity of manners.

xenia.explanation: The effect, such as an increase in size, on the embryo or endosperm of a plant, resulting from fertilization with pollen of a genetically distinct variety.
The concept of hospitality to strangers.
The effect that genes from pollen have on the endosperm .

xenial.explanation: Hospitable , especially to visiting strangers or foreigners .
Of the relation between a host and guest ; friendly.

xenicidae.explanation: alternative names for the family comprising the New Zealand wrens

xenium.explanation: In classical antiquity , a present given to a guest or stranger, or to a foreign ambassador.
A present given to a guest or stranger, or to a foreign ambassador.

xenobiology.explanation: The speculative biology of extraterrestrial life forms

xenobiosis.explanation: The form of social symbiosis among ants which exists when two colonies of different species live together on friendly terms without bringing up their brood in common.

xenoblast.explanation: A metamorphic mineral that does not have characteristic mineral faces due to the conditions in which it grew.
A crystal forming in a metamorphic rock that has not developed its characteristic crystalline faces and which gets its shape from bordering crystals.

xenocryst.explanation: A crystal foreign to the igneous rock in which it occurs.
In petrography , a term proposed by Sollas for a crystal in an igneous rock which has been included by the igneous magma before the solidification of the rock.
a crystal that does not occur in a specific igneous rock

xenoderm.explanation: A wart-snake of the subfamily Xenodermatinæ.

xenodiagnosis.explanation: Diagnosis of an infectious disease at an early stage by exposing a presumably infected individual or tissue to a clean, laboratory-bred mosquito, tick, or other vector and then examining the vector for the presence of the infective microorganism.
diagnosis of an infectious disease (especially of trypanosomiasis ) by exposure to a vector of that disease, incubating the vector and examining it for the presence of the disease

xenodochium.explanation: A house for the reception of strangers.
In the Middle Ages, a room in a monastery for the reception and entertainment of strangers and pilgrims, and for the relief of paupers. [Called also Xenodocheion .]
A room (or separate guesthouse ) in a monastery for the temporary accommodation of guests or pilgrims .

xenogamy.explanation: In botany , cross-fertilization—that is, the impregnation or fecundation of the ovules of a flower with pollen from another flower of the same species, either on the same or (usually) on a different plant.
The transfer of pollen from the anthers of one plant to the stigma of another; cross-pollination .

xenogeneic.explanation: Derived or obtained from an organism of a different species.
Derived from a different species and therefore genetically and immunologically incompatible
denoting or relating to cells or tissues from individuals belonging to different species

xenogenesis.explanation: The supposed production of offspring markedly different from either parent.

The generation of offspring which pass through an entirely different life-cycle from that of the parents, and never exhibit the characters of the latter: a mode of biogenesis supposed by Milne-Edwards to occur, but not proved to have any existence in fact.
The fancied production of an organism of one kind by an organism of another.
The production of an offspring that is unlike either of its parents .
the alternation of two or more different forms in the life cycle of a plant or animal

xenogenetic.explanation: Being of foreign origin; having originated elsewhere.

xenogenic.explanation: Originating outside an organism and being introduced .

xenogenous.explanation: pathology , originating from causes outside of the body.

xenograft.explanation: tissue from an animal of one species used as a temporary graft (as in cases of severe burns) on an individual of another species

xenolite.explanation: A silicate of aluminium, related to fibrolite, found at Petershoff, Finland.

xenolith.explanation: A rock fragment foreign to the igneous mass in which it occurs.
In petrography , a term proposed by Sollas (1894) for a rock inclosed in an intrusive rock, and not derived from the igneous magma.
any piece of rock having a different origin to that of the igneous rock in which it is found
(geology) a piece of rock of different origin from the igneous rock in which it is embedded

xenolithic.explanation: Being or pertaining to a xenolith .

xenomania.explanation: A mania for foreign persons or things.
A mania for, or an inordinate attachment to, foreign customs, institutions, manners, fashions, etc.
A strong preference for foreign customs, manners, or institutions; the gaining of pleasure from meeting strangers or visiting foreign countries.

xenomi.explanation: A suborder of fishes, resembling the Haplomi , but distinguished by peculiarities of the pectoral arch (whence the name). It consists of the family Dalliidæ alone. See cut under Dallia .
A suborder of soft-rayed fresh-water fishes of which the blackfish of Alaska ( Dallia pectoralis ) is the type.

xenomorphic.explanation: lithology , noting the mineral constituents of a rock when they are bounded by planes not formed as the result of their own molecular structure, but the result of their contact with other minerals also forming constituents of the same rock, which having crystallized first have impressed their form on those adjacent to them: the counterpart of idiomorphic. Also called allotriomorphic .
noting or pertaining to a mineral grain that does not have its characteristic crystalline form but has a form impressed on it by surrounding grains; anhedral
in an unusual form; having a strange form

xenon.explanation: A colorless, odorless, noble gas element found in minute quantities in the atmosphere, extracted commercially from liquefied air and used in stroboscopic, bactericidal, and laser-pumping lamps. Atomic number 54; atomic weight 131.29; melting point −111.74°C; boiling point −108.09°C; density (gas) 5.89 grams per liter; specific gravity (liquid, at −109°C) 2.95; valence 0, 2, 4, 6. cross-reference : Periodic Table .
In chem. , the heaviest of the five recently discovered elementary substances present in gaseous form in the atmosphere.

A very heavy, inert gaseous element of the noble gas group, occurring in the atmosphere in the proportion of one volume is about 20 millions. It was discovered by Ramsay and Travers in 1898. It can be condensed to a liquid boiling at -107° C., and to a solid which melts at -111.9° C. Symbol Xe (formely also X); atomic number 54; atomic weight 131.3.
A heavy, gaseous chemical element (symbol Xe) of the noble gases group with an atomic number of 54.
a colorless odorless inert gaseous element occurring in the earth's atmosphere in trace amounts

xenoparasite.explanation: A parasitic fungus which is able to infect a certain host-plant only when that host is wounded or otherwise injured. Compare œoparasite .
An ectoparasite that becomes pathogenic only when the host is weakened or injured

xenoparasitism.explanation: The particular form of parasitism shown by a xenoparasite. See the extract under xenoparasite .

xenophile.explanation: A person attracted to that which is foreign, especially to foreign peoples, manners, or cultures.
A person infatuated with foreign people and culture.
A person very interested in celebrating people's differences.

xenophobe.explanation: A person who is fearful or contemptuous of that which is foreign, especially of strangers or of people from different countries or cultures.
One who fears that which is unknown ; one who fears people who are different from oneself , especially in the case of foreign people

xenophobia.explanation: A fear of strangers or foreigners .
A strong antipathy or aversion to strangers or foreigners.
a fear of foreigners or strangers

xenophobic.explanation: Suffering from xenophobia , a fear or hatred of strangers or foreigners
suffering from xenophobia; having abnormal fear or hatred of the strange or foreign

xenophora.explanation: The typical genus of Xenophoridæ , so called from their carrying foreign objects attached to the shell. Formerly also called Phorus (a name too near the prior Phora in entomology). See also cut under carrier-shell .
Any mollusk of the genus Xenophora .

xenophthalmia.explanation: Conjunctivitis excited by the presence of a foreign body.
ophthalmia caused by foreign matter in the eye

xenopodidae.explanation: in some classifications the family of the genus Xenopus which is otherwise included in the family Pipidae

xenopterygii.explanation: A suborder of teleocephalous fishes, represented by the family Gobiesocidæ , and characterized by the development of a complicated suctorial organ in the pectoral region.
A suborder of fishes including Gobiesox and allied genera. These fishes have soft-rayed fins, and a ventral sucker supported in front by the pectoral fins. They are destitute of scales.

xenopus.explanation: Any of various aquatic, tongueless, clawed frogs of the genus Xenopus of southern Africa, certain species of which, especially the African clawed frog, are widely used for biological research.

xenorhynchus.explanation: A genus of storks or Ciconiinæ , representing the Indian and Australian type of jabirus. X. australis is the black-necked stork (which see, under stork ).

xenotime.explanation: A native phosphate of yttrium, having a yellowish-brown color, and crystallizing in squares, octahedrons, and prisms. It resembles zircon in form, but is inferior in hardness.
A native phosphate of yttrium occurring in yellowish-brown tetragonal crystals.
A yellow-brown mineral , yttrium phosphate ( Y P O 4)
a brown-to-yellow mineral that is a phosphate of yttrium in crystalline form

xenotropic.explanation: Describing a virus growing in tissue of an organism other than its normal host

xenurus.explanation: In mammalogy , a genus of armadillos, named by Wagler in 1830; the xenurines or kabassous.

xenyl.explanation: The radical characteristic of xenylic compounds.
The univalent radical derived from diphenyl

xerafin.explanation: An Indo-Portuguese silver coin formerly current in Goa. About 1835 it was worth 75 United States cents.

xeransis.explanation: In pathology , siccation; a drying up.

xeranthemum.explanation: A genus of composite plants, of the tribe Cynaroideæ and subtribe Carlineæ.
Any of the genus Xeranthemum of flowering plants native to Southern Europe .
any plant of the genus Xeranthemum native to southern Europe having chaffy or silvery flower heads with purplish tubular flowers

xerasia.explanation: A disease of the hair, characterized by excessive dryness and cessation of growth.
dryness and brittleness of the hair

xeric.explanation: Of, characterized by, or adapted to an extremely dry habitat.
Said of an environment or habitat that is extremely dry , lacking humidity and water.
Said of an organism adapted to live in a very dry habitat .

xeriff.explanation: A gold coin formerly current in Egypt and Turkey, of the value of about 9s. 6d., or about $2.30; -- also, in Morocco, a ducat.
A gold coin once current in Egypt and Turkey .

xeroderma.explanation: Excessive or abnormal dryness of the skin, as in ichthyosis.
A mild form of ichthyosis, in which the skin is dry and harsh in consequence of diminished activity of the sudorific and sebaceous glands. Also called dermatoxerasia and dryskin.
A skin disease characterized by the presence of numerous small pigmented spots resembling freckles, with which are subsequently mingled spots of atrophied skin.
Any of various skin diseases characterised by dry hard scaly skin, especially ichthyosis .
a mild form of ichthyosis characterized by abnormal dryness and roughness of the skin

xerodermia.explanation: a mild form of ichthyosis characterized by abnormal dryness and roughness of the skin

xerogel.explanation: a solid formed by the dehydration of a gel

xerographic.explanation: of, relating to, or produced by xerography

xerographically.explanation: In a xerographic way; by xerography .

xerography.explanation: A dry photographic or photocopying process in which a negative image formed by a resinous powder on an electrically charged plate is electrically transferred to and thermally fixed as positive on a paper or other copying surface.
a photocopying process in which a negative image formed on an electrically charged plate is transferred as a positive to paper and thermally fixed
forming an image by the action of light on a specially coated charged plate; the latent image is developed with powders that adhere only to electrically charged areas

xeroma.explanation: abnormal dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea of the eyes; may be due to a systemic deficiency of vitamin A

xeromenia.explanation: The absence of menses during a menstrual period

xeromorph.explanation: any plant, with xeromorphic leaves, that is adapted to a dry atmosphere; a xerophyte

xeromorphic.explanation: Of or relating to any of the structural adaptations characteristic of xerophytes, such as water-storing stems or leaves.
of, relating to, or characteristic of the xerophytes , especially having the ability to store water in leaves and stems

xeronic.explanation: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid, C8H12O4, related to fumaric acid, and obtained from citraconic acid as an oily substance having a bittersweet taste; -- so called from its tendency to form its anhydride.
Relating to xeronic acid or its derivatives

xerophagy.explanation: The habit of living on dry food, especially a form of abstinence, as in the early church, in which only bread, herbs, salt, and water were consumed.
Among the primitive Christians, the living on a diet of dry food in Lent and on other fasts.
A restrictive diet (of bread and water , for example) as a punishment or religious form of discipline .

xerophil.explanation: In botany , a plant of Alphonse de Candolle's second “physiological group” in his natural system of geographical distribution.

xerophile.explanation: An organism that flourishes in a very dry environment.
plant adapted for life with a limited supply of water; compare hydrophyte and mesophyte

xerophilous.explanation: Flourishing in a very dry environment.
xerophyte and equivalent to xerophytic , properly in sense 1: first used by Thurmann (1849), who regarded xerophilous plants as correlated with dysgeogenous soils. See quotation under silicicolous .
Drought-loving; able withstand the absence or lack of moisture.
Being able to thrive in dry weather.

xerophily.explanation: In phytogeography , the character of being xerophilous or the occurrence of such character.

xerophthalmia.explanation: Extreme dryness and thickening of the conjunctiva, often resulting from a deficiency of vitamin A.
A dry form of conjunctivitis, resulting in a thickening and skin-like condition of the conjunctiva. Also xeroma , and xerosis of the conjunctiva.
An abnormal dryness of the eyeball produced usually by long-continued inflammation and subsequent atrophy of the conjunctiva.

A condition due to a deficiency of vitamin A where the conjunctiva and cornea become dry . The condition starts with conjunctival xerosis and night blindness and progresses to corneal xerosis and, later, a severe condition called keratomalacia .
abnormal dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea of the eyes; may be due to a systemic deficiency of vitamin A

xerophyllum.explanation: A genus of liliaceous plants, of the tribe Narthecieæ.
[ lowercase ] A plant of this genus.
small genus of North American herbs having grasslike basal leaves: squaw grass; sometimes placed in family Melanthiaceae

xerophyte.explanation: A plant adapted to surviving with little water.
In phytogeography , a plant adapted to live under conditions of small available moisture.
Any plant suited for life in a habitat where water is scarce , such as in a desert or chaparral . Such plants may be succulent , have small or reduced leaves , or spines .
plant adapted for life with a limited supply of water; compare hydrophyte and mesophyte

xerophytic.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or being a xerophyte .
adapted to a xeric (or dry) environment

xerophytism.explanation: In plant ecology , adaptation to arid conditions; xerophily.

xerosere.explanation: The succession of ecological communities which originated in an extremely dry habitat such as a sand desert, sand dunes, a salt desert or a rock desert.

xerosis.explanation: Abnormal dryness, especially of the skin, eyes, or mucous membranes.
The normal hardening of aging tissue.

xerostoma.explanation: The condition of having a dry mouth .

xerostomia.explanation: abnormal dryness of the mouth resulting from decreased secretion of saliva

xerotes.explanation: In medicine , a dry habit or disposition of the body.
A general dryness of the body
the condition of not containing or being covered by a liquid (especially water)

xerothermic.explanation: Adapted to or flourishing in an environment that is both dry and hot.
That flourishes in hot, dry conditions

xerox.explanation: To make a paper copy or copies by means of a photocopier .

xeroxed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of xerox .

xeroxes.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of xerox .

xerus.explanation: A genus of African ground-squirrels, having dry, harsh fur, which in some cases is bristly and even spiny.

xi.explanation: The 14th letter of the Greek alphabet.
The Greek letter Ξ , ξ , corresponding to the English x.
The Greek letter Ξ , ξ , corresponding to the English x and z.
The name for the 14th letter of Classical and Modern Greek . The 15th in Ancient and Old Greek .
Either of a pair of hyperons having spin 1/2, which decay into a lambda particle and a pion .
the cardinal number that is the sum of ten and one
the 14th letter of the Greek alphabet

xii.explanation: denoting a quantity consisting of 12 items or units
the cardinal number that is the sum of eleven and one

xiii.explanation: the cardinal number that is the sum of twelve and one

ximenia.explanation: A genus of polypetalous plants, of the order Olacineæ and tribe Olaceæ.

xiphias.explanation: The typical genus of Xiphiidæ , now restricted to swordfishes without teeth or ventral fins, and thus exclusive of the sailfishes and spear-fishes ( Histiophorus and Tetrapturus ).
A constellation made by Petrus Theodori in the fifteenth century, in the south pole of the ecliptic, and now named Dorado.
[ lowercase ] In older authors, a sword-shaped comet.
A genus of fishes comprising the common swordfish.
A comet shaped like a sword.

xiphihumeralis.explanation: A muscle which in some animals passes from the xiphoid cartilage to the proximal end of the humerus.
A long, flat strip of pectoral muscle comprising a band of parallel fibres , found in felines .

xiphioid.explanation: Xiphiidæ , or having their characters. Also xiphiiform .
A member of the family Xiphiidæ.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a cetacean of the genus Xiphius or family Xiphiidæ .
resembling or related to the genus Xiphias (swordfish).
resembling or related to the family Xiphiidae (a group of fish ).
Any member of the genus Xiphias or family Xiphiidae .

xiphiplastron.explanation: The fourth lateral piece of the plastron of a turtle; one of the pair of terminal pieces of the plastron in Chelonia , called xiphisternum by some. See cuts under plastron and Chelonia.
The posterior, or fourth, lateral plate in the plastron of turtles; -- called also xiphisternum .
the posterior, or fourth lateral plate in the plastron of a turtle

xiphisternal.explanation: anatomy , of the nature of the xiphisternum, or last sterneber of the sternum; pertaining to the xiphisternum; ensiform or xiphoid, as a cartilage or bone of the breast-bone.
Chelonia , xiphiplastral. See cuts under Chelonia and plastron.
of, or relating to the xiphisternum

xiphisternum.explanation: The hindmost segment or division of the sternum, corresponding to the xiphoid appendage or ensiform cartilage of man.
The xiphiplastron of a turtle. See second cut under Chelonia .
The posterior segment, or extremity, of the sternum; -- sometimes called metasternum , ensiform cartilage , ensiform process , or xiphoid process .
The xiphoid process , a small cartilaginous extension to the lower part of the sternum , usually ossified in the adult human .

xiphisura.explanation: In Latreille's classification, the first family of his Pœcilopoda , contrasted with his Siphonostoma , and containing only the genus Limulus. Compare Synziphosura . See cuts under horseshoe-crab and Limulus.

xiphius.explanation: A genus of cetaceans having a long, pointed, bony beak, usually two tusklike teeth in the lower jaw, but no teeth in the upper jaw.

xiphocostal.explanation: Pertaining to the xiphoid process and the ribs .

xiphodon.explanation: A genus of fossil artiodactyl mammals, of Eocene age and small size, now referred to the Dichobunidæ.
An extinct genus of artiodactylous mammals found in the European Tertiary formations. It had slender legs, didactylous feet, and small canine teeth.
A an extinct camel-like animal of genus, Xiphodon .

xiphodynia.explanation: Pain in the region of the ensiform appendage of the sternum.

xiphoid.explanation: Of or relating to the xiphoid process.
The ensiform or xiphoid cartilage in man, or its representative in other animals. See xiphisternum , 1.
Of or pertaining to the xiphoid process; xiphoidian.
Of, or relating to the xiphisternum .

xiphopagus.explanation: In teratology , a double monster connected by a band extending from the ensiform cartilage to the umbilicus. The Siamese twins constituted a xiphopagus. Also xiphodidymus .
Either of a pair of congenitally joined twins ( Siamese twin ) united at the xiphoid process .

xiphosura.explanation: Same as Xiphisura : in this form, in Lankester's classification, brought under Arachnida as one of three orders (the other two being Eurypterina and Trilobitæ ) brigaded under the name Delobranchia.

xiphosuran.explanation: Any of various arthropods of the order Xiphosura, having a long pointed telson extending from the rear of the abdomen. The order includes the horseshoe crabs and many extinct species.
A member of the group Xiphosura ; a xiphosure.
Any member of the order Xiphosura , including horseshoe crabs .
Of or pertaining to the order Xiphosura .

xiphosure.explanation: One of the Xiphosura , as a horseshoe-crab.
One of the Xiphosura , as a horseshoe-crab.

xiphura.explanation: The more proper form of Xiphisura .
Same as limuloidea . Called also Xiphosura .

xiphydria.explanation: In entomology , a notable genus of hymenopterous insects, of the family Uroceridæ , or typical of a family Xiphydriidæ , having the ovipositor considerably exserted, the neck elongate, and certain peculiar venational characters.

xiv.explanation: the cardinal number that is the sum of thirteen and one

xix.explanation: the cardinal number that is the sum of eighteen and one

xoanon.explanation: In anc. Gr. art , a work of sculpture of the most ancient and primitive class, rudely formed in wood, the eyes being generally represented closed, and the limbs, when indicated at all, extended stiffly.

xonotlite.explanation: A mineral with the chemical formula Ca6Si6O17(OH)2, found in various colours .

xu.explanation: A minor unit of currency in Vietnam, now little-used, forming a hundredth of a dong .

xurel.explanation: Either of two carangoid fishes, Trachurus picturatus of the east Pacific and east Atlantic, and Caranx latus of the warm and tropical American Atlantic and Pacific.

xvi.explanation: the cardinal number that is the sum of fifteen and one

xvii.explanation: the cardinal number that is the sum of sixteen and one

xviii.explanation: the cardinal number that is the sum of seventeen and one

xx.explanation: Symbols or designations noting ale of certain qualities or degrees of strength, derived originally from marks on the brewers' casks. Compare X , 5.
(genetics) normal complement of sex chromosomes in a female
denoting a quantity consisting of 20 items or units
the cardinal number that is the sum of nineteen and one

xxi.explanation: the cardinal number that is the sum of twenty and one

xxii.explanation: the cardinal number that is the sum of twenty-one and one

xxiii.explanation: the cardinal number that is the sum of twenty-two and one

xxiv.explanation: the cardinal number that is the sum of twenty-three and one

xxv.explanation: the cardinal number that is the sum of twenty-four and one

xxx.explanation: XXX, The Roman numeral for thirty ( 30 )
An abbreviation for kisses , usually placed at the end of a letter, often placed alongside ooo , or in a text message .
(genetics) abnormal complement of three X chromosomes in a female
the cardinal number that is the product of ten and three

xylan.explanation: A yellow, water-soluble, gummy polysaccharide found in plant cell walls and yielding xylose upon hydrolysis.

A gelasinous, levorotatory compound, C 5 H 8 -O 4 (?), contained in all kinds of wood. With sulphuric acid it yields the sugar xylose; boiling mineral acids convert it chiefly into fur-furaldehyde. It is also called wood-gum .
A gummy substance of the pentosan class, present in woody tissue, and yielding xylose on hydrolysis; wood gum.
A polysaccharide , consisting of xylose residues, found in the cell walls of some algae and plants.

xylanthrax.explanation: Wood coal, or charcoal; -- so called in distinction from mineral coal .
Wood coal or charcoal , distinguished from mineral coal; lignite .

xylaria.explanation: A large genus of pyrenomycetous fungi having erect, black stipitate, cylindrical or clavate, simple or branched, corky stromata covered with a layer of perithecia.
type genus of Xylariaceae; fungi with perithecia in the upper part of erect black woody stromata

xylariaceae.explanation: family of fungi characterized by dark brown to black spores

xylate.explanation: Any salt or ester of xylic acid.

xyleborus.explanation: A notable genus of bark-boring beetles, of the family Scolytidæ , having the antennal funicle five-jointed, the club subglobose and subannulate, the tarsi with the first three joints subequal and simple, and the tibiæ with the outer edge curved and finely serrate.

xylem.explanation: The tissue of vascular plants that conducts water and minerals, provides support, and consists of tracheary elements and parenchyma cells. Woody tissue is made of secondary xylem produced by the vascular cambium.
In botany , that part of a fibrovascular bundle which contains ducts or tracheids—that is, the woody part, as distinguished from the phloëm, or bast part. Compare phloëm . See protoxylem, leptoxylem.
That portion of a fibrovascular bundle which has developed, or will develop, into wood cells; -- distinguished from phloëm .
A vascular tissue in land plants primarily responsible for the distribution of water and minerals taken up by the roots; also the primary component of wood .
the woody part of plants: the supporting and water-conducting tissue, consisting primarily of tracheids and vessels

xylene.explanation: Any of three colorless flammable isomeric benzene derivatives, C 8 H 10 , obtained from wood and coal tar.
A mixture of xylene isomers used as a solvent in making lacquers and rubber cement and as an aviation fuel.
Any one of the three metameric dimethyl benzines C 6 H 4 (CH 3 ) 2 . They are volatile, inflammable liquids obtained from wood-spirit and from coal-tar. Also xylol, xylole.

Any of a group of three metameric hydrocarbons of the aromatic series, found in coal and wood tar, and so named because found in crude wood spirit. They are colorless, oily, inflammable liquids, C6H4.(CH3)2, being dimethyl benzenes, and are called respectively orthoxylene , metaxylene , and paraxylene . Called also xylol .
Any of a group of three isomeric aromatic hydrocarbons , di-methyl-benzene, found in coal and wood tar .
a colorless flammable volatile liquid hydrocarbon used as a solvent

xylenol.explanation: In organic chemistry , any one of six colorless, crystalline compounds, (CH 3 ) 2 C 6 -H 3 OH, closely resembling phenol in general properties.
Any one of six metameric phenol derivatives of xylene, obtained as crystalline substances, (CH3)2.C6H3.OH.
An arene compound with two methyl groups and a hydroxyl group.

xyletic.explanation: Pertaining to, or designating, a complex acid related to mesitylenic acid, obtained as a white crystalline substance by the action of sodium and carbon dioxide on crude xylenol.

xylic.explanation: Pertaining to, derived from, or related to, xylene; specifically, designating any one of several metameric acids produced by the partial oxidation of mesitylene and pseudo-cumene.

xylidic.explanation: Pertaining to, or designating, either one of two distinct acids which are derived from xylic acid and related compounds, and are metameric with uvitic acid.
Of or pertaining to either of two acids derived from xylic acid and related compounds, metameric with uvitic acid .

xylidine.explanation: Any of six toxic isomeric anilines, C 8 H 11 N, derived from xylene, used chiefly as dye intermediates.
Any of various mixtures of xylidine isomers.

In chem. , an amine derivative from the hydrocarbon xylene, itself obtained from coal-tar. The general formula for xylidine is C 6 H 3 (CH 3 ) 2 NH 2 , but there are six isomeric forms, of which two form the greater part of the oily liquid industrially known under this name and used in the manufacture of artificial dyestuffs.

Any one of six metameric hydrocarbons, (CH3)2.C6H3.NH2, resembling aniline, and related to xylene. They are liquids, or easily fusible crystalline substances, of which three are derived from metaxylene, two from orthoxylene, and one from paraxylene. They are called the amido xylenes .
Any of six isomeric aromatic amines (CH3)2C6H3NH2 derived from the xylenes

xylindein.explanation: A blue compound contained in green, decayed wood which has been infected with Peziza æruginosa. It crystallizes in quadratic plates which have a strong coppery luster.
A green or blue pigment produced by Peziza in certain kinds of decayed wood, as the beech, oak, birch, etc., and extracted as an amorphous powder resembling indigo.
A quinone pigment , a dimeric naphthoquinone derivative , responsible for the characteristic bluish-green stain of wood infected by the Chlorociboria aeruginascens mushroom .

xylinid.explanation: A member of the lepidopterous family Xylinidæ.

xylite.explanation: A colorless carbohydrate, C 5 H 12 O 5 , prepared by the reduction of xylose.
A colorless liquid obtained from crude wood-spirit. It boils at 61.5° C.
A liquid hydrocarbon found in crude wood spirits.
A liquid hydrocarbon found in crude wood spirits .

xylitol.explanation: A sweet white crystalline alcohol derived from xylose, C 5 H 12 O 5 , used in gum and oral health products to inhibit bacteria that cause caries and as a dietary sugar substitute.
a pentahydric alcohol , C5H12O5, penta-hydroxy pentane; derived from xylose ; used as a sweetener

xylitone.explanation: A yellow oil having a geraniumlike odor, produced as a side product in making phorone; -- called also xylite oil .
A yellow oil that is a side product of making phorone .

xylobalsamum.explanation: The wood, or particularly the dried twigs, of the balm-of-Gilead tree, Commiphora Opobalsamum.
The balsam obtained by decoction from this wood.
The dried twigs of a Syrian tree ( Balsamodendron Gileadense ).
the dried twigs or fragrant wood of balm of Gilead (or balsam of Mecca)

xylocarp.explanation: In botany , a hard and woody fruit.

xylocarpous.explanation: Bearing fruit which becomes hard or woody.
Bearing fruit that becomes hard or woody .

xylocopa.explanation: An extensive genus of solitary bees, containing many of those large species known as carpenter-bees.
A genus of hymenopterous insects including the carpenter. See Carpenter bee, under carpenter .

xylogen.explanation: Wood or xylem in a formative state.
Nascent wood; wood cells in a forming state.
Nascent wood ; wood cells in a forming state.

xyloglyphy.explanation: The art of carving in wood.

xylograph.explanation: To print from a wood engraving.
An impression or print from a wood-block. In both senses the term is most commonly applied to old work, especially to that of the very earliest period.
A mechanical copy of the grain of wood, executed by a method of nature-printing, and used as a surface decoration.
An engraving on wood, or the impression from such an engraving; a print by xylography.
An engraving in wood , especially one used for printing .
A print taken from an engraving in wood.
To make a print from an engraving in wood .

xylographer.explanation: An engraver on wood, especially one of the earliest wood-engravers, as of the fifteenth century.

xylographic.explanation: Of or pertaining to xylography, or wood engraving.

xylography.explanation: Wood engraving, especially of an early period.
The art of printing texts or illustrations, sometimes with color, from woodblocks, as distinct from typography.
Engraving on wood: a word used only by bibliographers, and chiefly for the woodcut work of the fifteenth century.
A process of decorative painting on wood.
The art of engraving on wood.
The art of making prints from the natural grain of wood.
A method pf printing in colors upon wood for purposes of house decoration.

xyloidin.explanation: A substance resembling pyroxylin, obtained by the action of nitric acid on starch; -- called also nitramidin .
A compound resembling pyroxylin , obtained by the action of nitric acid on starch .

xyloidine.explanation: An explosive compound (C 6 H 9 NO 7 ) produced by the action of strong nitric acid upon starch or woody fiber. It somewhat resembles guncotton in its nature. Also called xylidine .

xylol.explanation: a colorless flammable volatile liquid hydrocarbon used as a solvent

xylology.explanation: The branch of dendrology treating of the gross and minute structure of wood.
the study of wood . A term that is rarely used, but see palaeoxylology .

xyloma.explanation: In botany , a scleriotoid body in certain fungi which produces sporogenous structures in its interior.

xylomancy.explanation: divination by means of pieces of burning wood

xylometer.explanation: An instrument for ascertaining the specific gravity of wood.
an instrument used to determine the specific gravity of wood

xylonic.explanation: Relating to xylonic acid or its derivatives

xylophaga.explanation: A genus of boring bivalves, of the family Pholadidæ , as X. dorsalis.
[ lowercase ] A member of this genus.

A series of Hymenoptera ditrocha , in Hartig's classification (1837), containing only the family Uroceridæ : distinguished from the Phyllophaga on the one hand and the Parasitica on the other. Compare these two words.
A genus of marine bivalves which bore holes in wood. They are allied to Pholas.

xylophagan.explanation: entomology , of or pertaining to the Xylophaga , in either sense.
A member of the Xylophaga , in either sense.
One of a tribe of beetles whose larvæ bore or live in wood.
Any insect of the genus Xylophaga, which bores into wood.

xylophage.explanation: Any living organism that feeds on wood .

xylophagid.explanation: A member of the dipterous family Xylophagidæ.

xylophagous.explanation: Feeding on or obtaining nutrition from wood.
Eating, boring in, or destroying, wood; -- said especially of certain insect larvæ, crustaceans, and mollusks.
Of or pertaining to the genus Xylophaga.

xylophilous.explanation: Growing or living on or in wood.
phytogeography , growing on wood in any state: applied to a class of fungi.
Of or pertaining to the xylophilans.
Living on or in wood , as some fungi and beetles do.

xylophone.explanation: A percussion instrument consisting of a mounted row of wooden bars that are graduated in length to sound a chromatic scale, played with two small mallets.

A musical instrument consisting of a graduated series of wooden bars, often supported on bands of straw, and sounded by means of small wooden hammers or by rubbing with rosined gloves. The tone is often agreeable and effective. Also gigelira, sticcada , and strawfiddle.

An instrument common among the Russians, Poles, and Tartars, consisting of a series of strips of wood or glass graduated in length to the musical scale, resting on belts of straw, and struck with two small hammers. Called in Germany strohfiedel , or straw fiddle .
An instrument to determine the vibrative properties of different kinds of wood.
a musical instrument made of wooden slats graduated so as to make the sounds of the scale when struck with a small drumstick-like hammer.
a percussion instrument with wooden bars tuned to produce a chromatic scale and with resonators; played with small mallets

xylophonic.explanation: Of or pertaining to a xylophone .

xylophonist.explanation: A person who plays or performs with the xylophone.

xylopia.explanation: A genus of plants, of the order Anonaceæ , type of the tribe Xylopieæ.
tropical evergreen trees or shrubs; chiefly African

xyloplastic.explanation: Formed of wood pulp by molds; relating to casts made of wood pulp in molds.
Made from wood pulp shaped in a mould .

xylopyrography.explanation: The art or practice of burning pictures on wood with a hot iron; -- called also poker painting . See Poker picture, under poker .
the art of burning pictures onto wood

xyloquinone.explanation: Any one of a group of quinone compounds obtained respectively by the oxidation of certain xylidine compounds. In general they are yellow crystalline substances.
Any of a group of quinone compounds obtained by the oxidation of xylidines .

xylorcin.explanation: A derivative of xylene obtained as a white crystalline substance which on exposure in the air becomes red; -- called also betaorcin .
A derivative of xylene obtained as a white crystalline substance that turns red on exposure to air .

xylose.explanation: A white crystalline sugar, C 5 H 10 O 5 , that is a component of most hemicelluloses in plants.

A colorless, dextrorotatory carbohydrate, , prepared by the action of dilute sulphuric acid on wood-gum or corncobs. It reduces alkaline copper solutions, crystallizes in needles or orthorhombic prisms, and melts at 144–145° C. Also called wood-sugar .
An unfermentable sugar of the pentose class, C5H10O5, formed by the hydrolysis of xylan; wood sugar.
One of the pentoses , C5H10O5, a white crystalline substance, a sugar , derived from wood .
a sugar extracted from wood or straw; used in foods for diabetics

xylosma.explanation: Any of various evergreen shrubs and small trees in the genus Xylosma
shrub or small tree grown as an ornamental in mild climates for its neat evergreen foliage and fragrant late flowers; native of China

xylostroma.explanation: A genus or form-genus of polyporoid fungi, which continues indefinitely, without fruiting, as a thick dense leathery sheet covering the wood upon which it lives.
the felted stroma of various wood-destroying fungi

xylostromatoid.explanation: botany , resembling the genus or form-genus Xylostroma —that is, having a tough woody or leathery appearance—as the matted mycelium of certain polyporoid fungi.

xylotile.explanation: A mineral of fibrous structure and wood-brown color, probably an altered form of asbestos.

xylotomist.explanation: One versed or engaged in xylotomy.

xylotomous.explanation: Capable of boring or cutting wood; -- said of many insects.
That bores or cuts into wood , as with certain insects.

xylotomy.explanation: The microscopic structure of the wood of a plant or group of plants.
The preparation and microscopic study of sections of wood.
Art of preparing sections (transverse, tangential, or radial) of wood, esp. by means of a microtome, for microscopic examination.
The art of preparing sections of wood (as by means of a microtome ) for microscopic examination.

xylotrya.explanation: A genus of marine bivalves closely allied to Teredo, and equally destructive to timber. One species ( Xylotrya fimbriata ) is very common on the Atlantic coast of the United States.

xylotypography.explanation: Printing using the medium of wooden blocks .

xylyl.explanation: Any one of three metameric radicals which are characteristic respectively of the three xylenes.
Any of several univalent radicals , of formula (CH3)2C6H3- derived from the three isomers of xylene:- ortho- , meta- and para- (di-methyl benzene).

xylylene.explanation: In organic chemistry , any one of the three isomeric bivalent radicals, (CH 3 ) 2 C 6 H 2 ⟨ [CH 3 ;CH 3 = 1,2; 1,3; or 1,4.] The term is homologous with phenylene and the derivatives of both radicals resemble each other in general properties.
Any one of three metameric radicals, CH2.C6H4.CH2, derived respectively from the three xylenes. Often used adjectively.

xyrichthys.explanation: In ichthyology , a genus of brilliantly colored labroid fishes, of tropical seas, known as razor-fishes.

xyrid.explanation: Any of several North American plants , of the genus Xyris , resembling sedges

xyridaceae.explanation: plants of tropical to temperate regions; usually in wet places

xyridaceous.explanation: Xyris ; belonging to the Xyrideæ ( Xyridaceæ ).
Of or pertaining to a natural order ( Xyrideæ ) of endogenous plants, of which Xyris is the type.
Belonging or pertaining to the Xyridaceae, a family of flowering plants .

xyridales.explanation: Farinosæ . In modern systems it is placed between the Arales and the Liliales , and embraces 11 families, of which the most important are the Xyridaceæ, Bromeliaceæ, Commelinaceæ , and Pontederiaceæ.

xyris.explanation: A genus of plants, type of the order Xyrideæ.
A genus of endogenous herbs with grassy leaves and small yellow flowers in short, scaly-bracted spikes; yellow-eyed grass. There are about seventeen species in the Atlantic United States.
Any member of the plant genus Xyris .
chiefly American marsh plants, having usually yellow flowers

xyst.explanation: In ancient architecture , a covered portico or open court, of great length in proportion to its width, in which athletes performed their exercises; or, in Roman villas, sometimes, a garden walk planted with trees. Also xystos, xystus.
A long and open portico, for athletic exercises, as wrestling, running, etc., for use in winter or in stormy weather.

xyster.explanation: A surgical instrument for scraping bones.
A surgeons' instrument for scraping bones.
A surgical instrument used to scrape bones .

xystus.explanation: [ capitalized ] [NL.] A generic name variously applied to certain hymenopterous, coleopterous, and lepidopterous insects.
A long and open portico within the gymnasium .
